results.title: The new santri : challenges to traditional religious authority in Indonesia
abstracts: This is a reference book providing insights into the religious situation in Indonesia. Its discusses and analyses the construction, contestation, pluralization, fragmentation, and segmentation of religious authority in Indonesian Islam.

results.title: Terrorism in Indonesia after “Islamic State”
abstracts: This publication explores the growth of violent extremism in Indonesia following the emergence of the Islamic State (IS) movement in 2014. Although IS networks have been quelled, other autonomous networks and cells have since emerged. As these are unknown entities, the Indonesian government face challenges dealing with them, and may repress all Islamist groups.

results.title: 诗性文化
abstracts: 作者讲述中华文化里的华夏淑世精神和礼乐文明, 表明应结合东、西方文明的精髓, 创造人类未来的命运.

results.title: The great learning
abstracts: The Great Learning (Da Xue) is the first of the Four Books of Confucian philosophy. This book has re-sentenced and arranged the contents of The Great Learning, giving it a more compact, scientific and hierarchical structure.

results.title: Voice : testimonies that speak of God's goodness
abstracts: This is a collection of personal stories of people transformed by the gospel. Interspersed among the stories are scripture quotations from the New King James Version of the Holy Bible and from the Holy Bible, New Living Translation. The stories are grouped by categories such as healing, freedom, protection, provision and transformation.

results.title: Faith of our fathers : finding god in ancient China
abstracts: The author discusses the relationship between God, China and its language. Due to the many similarities and belief in God as the only Creator, the author points out how Chinese characters manifest historical evidences and many aspects recorded in the Bible.

results.title: 7 mysteries of ancient China
abstracts: This is a Manga adaptation of "Faith of Our Fathers" by Dr Thong Chan Kei. It explores the ancient Chinese worship of One God – one who shares the same attributes as the God of the Bible, and includes evidence from Chinese characters, descriptions of this God (Shang Di) from classical Chinese writings, and China’s imperial sacrificial system.

results.title: Believe in happy miracles - 33 joyful affirmations
abstracts: This is a self-published book written by Jimmy Chua and Linh N.K. It contains 33 affirmations to be happy.

results.title: Restoring the good news of everlasting life : transformational knowledge for the last generations of mortals
abstracts: This book, written by John Elijah, seeks to introduce readers to the evolution of man’s consciousness, from the perspective of Jesus Christ.

results.title: Living happy! : 33 joyful affirmations
abstracts: This is a self-published book written by Jimmy Chua. It contains 33 affirmations to be happy.

results.title: 喜满禅心 : 幸福来自美丽的心
abstracts: 这是本从英文书 "The happiness of a beautiful mind" 翻译成中文的书. 这本书收集了燃灯禅师的弘法.

results.title: Happy times with happy food : 33 tips to discover yummy food everywhere
abstracts: This is a self-published book written by Jimmy Chua and Linh N. K. It contains 33 tips on how to discover delicious food everywhere.

results.title: The happiness of a beautiful mind
abstracts: This book, published by The Very Quiet Studio, contains a collection of a series of dhammatalks by Venerable Sayalay Dipankara, an ordained nun from Myanmar. The words are transcribed from audio recordings of Sayalay Dipankara's dhamma teachings.

results.title: Substance, meaning & consciousness : a generic theory of existence
abstracts: Acknowledgement -- 1. Prologue -- 2. Form and substance -- 3. Meaning of existence -- 4. Void field theory -- 5. Physical reality -- 6. Universe as a continuum -- 7. Process of cognition -- 8. Metaphysical pursuit -- 9. Spiritual quest -- 10. Hierarchy of spiritual needs -- 11. Purpose of life -- 12. Transformation of the mind -- 13. Focusing the mind -- 14. Transcendental meditation -- 15. Trans-sexualism -- 16. Disease and cure -- 17. Altruistic prognosis -- 18. Towards an egalitarian graceful society.

results.title: The Dhamma way : selected Dhamma talks in 2011 by Venerable K. Rathanasara
abstracts: This book contains a selected collection of Dhamma talks, given by Venerable K. Rathanasara in 2011.

results.title: The separation of waters
abstracts: Through this graphic novel, Milton Choo tries to explain the events that happened on the first six days of Genesis, with scientific explanations.

results.title: Friends in a broken world : thoughts on friendship from the Emmaus Road
abstracts: This book, written by author Tan Soo-Inn, contains five meditations from passage Luke 24:13-49, which focus on the encounter on the Emmaus Road. The book contains the author's observations on friendship.

results.title: Dr Happy-go-lucky : 33 tips for a happy PhD
abstracts: In this book, the author, Jimmy Chua, shares his views on taking up a Doctor of philosophy degree course.

results.title: Health and wholeness through the Holy Communion
abstracts: In this book, pastor Joseph Prince explains about the misconceptions about the Holy Communion, and addresses the issues that have caused Christians to shun the Lord's table.

results.title: Healing promises
abstracts: In this book, pastor Joseph Prince seeks to show Jesus's compassion and willingness to heal the reader.

results.title: Together alive : rediscovering the lost art of living in community
abstracts: In this book, pastor Lam Kuo Yung shares his views on the importance of the concepts of gospel and community, and how the church should recover the art of living in communities before the memory of it becomes totally wiped out.

results.title: Between the lines : an analytical appreciation of the Buddha's life. Vol. 1
abstracts: In this book, the author, Sylvia Bay, attempts to write about Buddha's life from a historical perspective, as a man rather than a divine being.

results.title: Follow Dao
abstracts: In this book, the author seeks to explain the Universal Laws of nature, through the essence of Dao. He then covers the history of Taoism, and finally translates the Chinese text of philosophical Taoism, which is the Dao De Jing (道德经).

results.title: Three jewels in Buddhism
abstracts: In this book, the author shares his knowledge, derived from his research and practice, on the Three Jewels in Buddhism, which refer to the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha.

results.title: 100 days of favor : daily readings from Unmerited favor
abstracts: In this book, pastor Joseph Prince shares his views on biblical meditation, and invites the reader to experience the unmerited favour of God.

results.title: Saccakiriya : the belief in the power of true speech in Theravada Buddhist tradition
abstracts: This book is a revised version of the author's doctoral thesis, which was completed at the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London. The author seeks to show that the belief in the power of true speech is common in the Theravada tradition.

results.title: The path to mysterious Tibet
abstracts: In this book, Singaporean journalist Frank Wong shares his knowledge of Tantricism, which includes celestial and other types of burials, reincarnation in Tibet, as well as holy places in Tibet.

results.title: The Benjamin generation
abstracts: In this book, pastor Joseph Prince shares two messages about the Benjamin generation, a generation marked by Jesus’ grace and favour.

results.title: The timeless gift : the ultimate guide to a meaningful life
abstracts: In this book, the founder of PropNex, Ismail Gafoor shares with his readers how one can live a life of fulfilment, abundance, and happiness.

results.title: The Gospel community : where sharing lives is sharing Christ
abstracts: In this book, pastor Lam Kuo Yung shares his church's experiences, and how important the concepts of "gospel" and "community" are for Christians.

results.title: Thinking from the Han : self, truth, and transcendence in Chinese and Western culture / David L. Hall and Roger T. Ames.
abstracts: "This book continues a comparative project begun with the authors' Thinking Through Confucius and Anticipating China. It continues the comparative discussions by focusing upon three concepts - self, truth, transcendence - which best illuminate the distinctive characters of the two cultures. "Self" specifies the meaning of the human subject, "truth" considers that subject's manner of relating to the world of which it is a part, and "transcendence" raises the issue as to whether the self/world relationship is grounded in something other than the elements resourced immediately in self and world. Considered together, the discussions of these concepts advertise in a most dramatic fashion the intellectual barriers currently existing between Chinese and Western thinkers. More importantly, these discussions reformulate Chinese and Western vocabularies in a manner that will enhance the possibilities of intercultural communication."--Jacket.

results.title: The linguistic turn in hermeneutic philosophy / Cristina Lafont ; translated by José Medina.
abstracts: Annotation The linguistic turn in German philosophy was initiated in the eighteenth century in the work of Johann Georg Hamann, Johann Gottfried von Herder, and Wilhelm von Humboldt. It was further developed in this century by Martin Heidegger, and Hans-Georg Gadamer extended its influence to contemporary philosophers such as Karl-Otto Apel and J?Habermas. This tradition focuses on the world-disclosing dimension of language, emphasizing its communicative over its cognitive function. Although this study is concerned primarily with the German tradition of linguistic philosophy, it is very much informed by the parallel linguistic turn in Anglo-American philosophy, especially the development of theories of direct reference. Cristina Lafont draws upon Hilary Putnam's work in particular to criticize the linguistic idealism and relativism of the German tradition, which she traces back to the assumption that meaning determines reference. Part I is a reconstruction of the linguistic turn in German philosophy from Hamann to Gadamer. Part II offers the deepest account to date of Habermas's approach to language. Part III shows how the shortcomings of German linguistic philosophy can be avoided by developing a consistent and more defensible version of Habermas' theory of communicative rationality.

results.title: Native pragmatism : rethinking the roots of American philosophy / Scott L. Pratt.
abstracts: Pragmatism is America's most distinctive philosophy. Generally, it has been understood as a development of European thought in response to the 'American wilderness'. A closer examination, however, reveals that the roots and central commitments of pragmatism are indigenous to North America. Native Pragmatism recovers this history and thus provides the means to re-conceive the scope and potential of American philosophy.

abstracts: Includes bibliographical references and indexes.

abstracts: "A Bradford book."

results.title: Emotions in Asian thought : a dialogue in comparative philosophy / edited by Joel Marks and Roger T. Ames ; with a discussion by Robert C. Solomon.
abstracts: This book broadens the inquiry into emotion to comprehend a comparative cultural outlook. It begins with an overview of recent work in the West, and then proceeds to the main business of scrutinizing various relevant issues from both Asian and comparative perspectives. Finally, Robert Solomon comments and summarizes.

results.title: Freud, the reluctant philosopher / Alfred I. Tauber.
abstracts: Freud began university intending to study both medicine and philosophy. But he was ambivalent about philosophy, regarding it as metaphysical, too limited to the conscious mind, and ignorant of empirical knowledge. Yet his private correspondence and his writings on culture and history reveal that he never forsook his original philosophical ambitions. Indeed, while Freud remained firmly committed to positivist ideals, his thought was permeated with other aspects of German philosophy. Placed in dialogue with his intellectual contemporaries, Freud appears as a reluctant philosopher who failed to r.

results.title: Simple sentences, substitution, and intuitions [electronic resource] / Jennifer Saul.
abstracts: The phenomenon of substitution failure is a longstanding focus of discussion for philosophers of language. Substitution failure occurs when a change from one co-referential name to another (e.g. from 'Superman' to 'Clark Kent') affects the truth-value of a sentence. Jennifer Saul has shown that this can occur even in the simplest of sentences. She presents the first full-length treatment of this puzzling feature of language, and explores its implications for the theory of referenceand names, and for the methodology of semantics.

abstracts: Includes bibliographical references (pages 241-257) and index.

results.title: The good life of teaching [electronic resource] : an ethics of professional practice / Chris Higgins.
abstracts: "The Good Life of Teaching extends the recent revival of virtue ethics to professional ethics and the philosophy of teaching. It connects long-standing philosophical questions about work and human growth to questions about teacher motivation, identity, and development. Makes a significant contribution to the philosophy of teaching and also offers new insights into virtue theory and professional ethics. Offers fresh and detailed readings of major figures in ethics, including Alasdair MacIntyre, Charles Taylor, and Bernard Williams and the practical philosophies of Hannah Arendt, John Dewey and Hans-Georg Gadamer. Provides illustrations to assist the reader in visualizing major points, and integrates sources such as film, literature, and teaching memoirs to exemplify arguments in an engaging and accessible way. Presents a compelling vision of teaching as a reflective practice showing how this requires us to prepare teachers differently "-- Provided by publisher.

results.title: Revealing male bodies [electronic resource] / edited by Nancy Tuana [and others].
abstracts: Revealing Male Bodies is the first scholarly collection to directly confront male lived experience. There has been an explosion of work in men's studies, masculinity issues, and male sexuality, in addition to a growing literature exploring female embodiment. Missing from the current literature, however, is a sustained analysis of the phenomenology of male-gendered bodies. Revealing Male Bodies addresses this omission by examining how male bodies are physically and experientially constituted by the economi.

results.title: 群的征服 : 人的演化、人的本性、人的社会, 如何让人成为地球的主导力量 = The social conquest of earth / 爱德华·威尔森著 ; 邓子衿译.
authors: 威尔森, 爱德华, author.
abstracts: 人类对自己在生物圈中的角色一直非常困惑、也非常矛盾. 动物界、脊索动物门、哺乳纲、灵长目、人科、人属、智人种, 由人猿/古猿演化而来; 人类跟所有生物一样, 有一个"生物学"上的分类系统可供栖身. 但人类也自诩有所谓的"文明", 社会性的积累让"人"有别于一般生物. 生物学家爱德华・威尔森试图从演化角度解答这个问题. 他在本书中提出"真社会性"的概念, 不只挑战过去半世纪用以解释动物利他行为的"自私基因"理论, 也试图为人类的文化及社会行为, 给出一个生物学上的说法. 威尔森认为天择筛选的是群体, 因此具有合作特质的真社会性群体拥有演化上的优势. 而真社会性的形成有几个重要演化步骤: 一、形成群体; 二、建立永久且具备防御功能的巢穴, 并留在巢中共同生活; 三、强化个体间合作, 并出现阶级性的分工; 四、天择对群体的筛选会进一步改变该物种的生活史和社会结构, 因而产生复杂的超生物. 人类这个群体因真社会性具有演化的优势, 但也因群体过于复杂, 导致群体中的成员仍须为了生存, 彼此竞争, 产生自私利己的行为. 利他与自私这两种矛盾的本性, 造就了人类复杂的社会行为与文化积累. 我们无法从外星人的尺度对人类进行观察, 于是威尔森以蚂蚁、蜜蜂等昆虫的观察为引, 从中延伸描述人类的生物性与特殊性, 兼纳人类学和脑神经科学的研究成果, 试图重新解释我们惯常以文化解释的社会行为, 并重新看待所谓人类的本性、人类的起源, 与未来.

results.title: The idea of human rights : four inquiries / Michael J. Perry.
abstracts: Includes bibliographical references (pages 107-157) and index.

results.title: Melville's muse [electronic resource] : literary creation & the forms of philosophical fiction / John Wenke.
abstracts: That Herman Melville was a philosophical fiction writer may be generally accepted, but the implications of this definition are unclear. In Melville's Muse, John Wenke discusses what it means - both biographically and textually - for Melville to combine philosophy and aesthetics. Wenke focuses on Melville's failures and successes in developing fictional forms to contain and express metaphysical speculations. He examines how the author appropriated and transformed elements of his Calvinist-Lutheran heritage; his eclectic reading in ancient, Renaissance, and contemporary writings; his Romantic Zeitgeist; and his cultural and political milieu. Through his analysis, he clearly shows that consciously articulated life choices led Melville to create texts that are both derivative and revolutionary. This study offers a new interpretation of some existing materials but also provides many specific discoveries of Melville's use of Plato, Francois Rabelais, Michel Eyquem de Montaigne, Robert Burton, Sir Thomas Browne, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Mary Shelley, Thomas Carlyle, and Ralph Waldo Emerson, among others. It combines traditional historicism with contemporary theoretical practice, resulting in an interdisciplinary jargon-free critical narrative. Of particular interest to specialists in Melvillean studies, American Romanticism, and 19th-century American literature, it also will appeal to scholars of philosophy and literature, literature and culture, and literary criticism.

results.title: This I believe [electronic resource] : life lessons / edited by Dan Gediman with John Gregory and Mary Jo Gediman.
abstracts: "Inspiring life wisdom from people of all ages--based on the This I Believe radio programThe popular This I Believe series, which has aired on NPR and on Bob Edwards' shows on Sirius XM Satellite and public radio, explores the personal beliefs and guiding principles by which Americans live today. This book brings together treasured life lessons of people from all walks of life. Whether it's learning the power of saying hello or how courage comes with practice, their intimate reflections will inspire, move, and encourage you. Filled with the valuable insights distilled from a wide range of personal experiences, This I Believe: Life Lessons is a perfect gift--for others or for yourself. Includes extraordinary essays written by "ordinary" people who share the story of an important lesson they have learned about life Shares a wide range of beliefs and experiences from a diverse group of contributors, including a physician, a roller derby queen, a corporate executive, a homeless person, and many others Based on the popular This I Believe radio series and thisibelieve.org website No matter what your age or circumstances, this book will give you valuable food for thought and important new insights on how others have learned from life's challenges"-- Provided by publisher.

"In this book, you'll find ponderings on life?s big questions, like "Why am I here"? and "What is my place in the world"? There are beliefs in the importance of saying hello, saying thank you, and saying ?I forgive you.? And there are revelations on the importance of listening to your inner voice and taking responsibility for one's actions"-- Provided by publisher.

results.title: Reality transformed : film as meaning and technique / Irving Singer.
abstracts: In Reality Transformed Irving Singer offers a new approach to the philosophy of film. Returning to the classical debate between realists and formalists, he shows how the opposing positions may be harmonized and united. He accepts the realist claim that films somehow "capture" reality, but agrees with the formalist belief that they transform it. Extending his earlier work on meaning in art and life, he suggests that the meaningfulness of movies derives from techniques that re-create reality in the process of presenting it to viewers who have learned how to appreciate the aesthetics of cinematic transformation.

results.title: The meaning of life [electronic resource] : a very short introduction / Terry Eagleton.
abstracts: We have all wondered about the meaning of life. Is there an answer? Is it up to us? Or is the question a bogus one? Terry Eagleton takes a witty, stimulating look at this most compelling of questions - and proposes his own answer. - ;'Philosophers have an infuriating habit of analysing questions rather than answering them', writes Terry Eagleton, who, in these pages, asks the most important question any of us ever ask, and attempts to answer it. So what is the meaning of life? In this witty, spirited, and stimulating inquiry, Eagleton shows how centuries of thinkers - from Shakespeare and Scho.

results.title: No rules for Michael [electronic resource] / Sylvia A. Rouss ; illustrated by Susan Simon.
abstracts: While studying the Ten Commandments Michael says he would rather there were no rules, but when his teacher gives him a day without rules, Michael learns an important lesson.

results.title: Daoist nei gong [electronic resource] : the philosophical art of change / Damo Mitchell ; foreword by Cindy Engel.
abstracts: Nei Gong has been a well-kept secret within the Daoist sects of China for centuries. Based upon the original teachings of the great sage Laozi, it has only ever been taught to close students of the masters chosen as the heads of the ancient orders. For the first time in the English language, this book describes the philosophy, principles and practice of Nei Gong. The author provides a breakdown of the entire Nei Gong process, and explains in plain English the philosophy which underpins Nei Gong practice, and which is based on the original teachings of the ancient Daoist priests. The methodology of Sung breathing, an advanced meditative practice which has until now been reserved for 'inner-door' students is described, and the book contains an entire set of Qigong exercises accompanied by instructional photographs and drawings. This book will be of interest to all practitioners of Qi Gong, martial arts and meditation, and will be a rewarding read for anyone interested in Eastern philosophy.

results.title: Golf and philosophy [electronic resource] : lessons from the links / edited by Andy Wible.
abstracts: In a game where players are expected to call their own penalties and scoring the least points leads to victory, decorum takes precedence over showmanship and philosophical questions become par for the course. Few other sports are as suited for ethical and metaphysical examination as golf. It is a game defined by dichotomies-relaxing, yet frustrating, social, yet solitary-and between these extremes there is room for much philosophical inquiry.In Golf and Philosophy: Lessons from the Links, a clubhouse full of skilled contributors tee off on a range of philosophical topics within the framework o.

results.title: The five secrets you must discover before you die / John Izzo.
abstracts: Presents advice that was gleaned from over 200 interviews with people over the age of sixty. This book helps readers to understand the common themes from the lives of those interviewed, the commonality of what really matters in their lives, and especially how to put this wisdom into practice.

results.title: Relevance in argumentation [electronic resource] / Douglas Walton.
abstracts: In Relevance in Argumentation, author Douglas Walton presents a new method for critically evaluating arguments for relevance. This method enables a critic to judge whether a move can be said to be relevant or irrelevant, and is based on case studies of argumentation in which a criticism has been made that an argument, or part of an argument, is irrelevant. The method is laso based on a new theory of relevance that incorporates techniques of argumentation theory, logic and artificial intelligence.

results.title: The Oxford dictionary of philosophy [electronic resource] / Simon Blackburn.
Melville's muse [electronic resource] : literary creation & the forms of philosophical fiction / John Wenke.
abstracts: That Herman Melville was a philosophical fiction writer may be generally accepted, but the implications of this definition are unclear. In Melville's Muse, John Wenke discusses what it means - both biographically and textually - for Melville to combine philosophy and aesthetics. Wenke focuses on Melville's failures and successes in developing fictional forms to contain and express metaphysical speculations. He examines how the author appropriated and transformed elements of his Calvinist-Lutheran heritage; his eclectic reading in ancient, Renaissance, and contemporary writings; his Romantic Zeitgeist; and his cultural and political milieu. Through his analysis, he clearly shows that consciously articulated life choices led Melville to create texts that are both derivative and revolutionary. This study offers a new interpretation of some existing materials but also provides many specific discoveries of Melville's use of Plato, Francois Rabelais, Michel Eyquem de Montaigne, Robert Burton, Sir Thomas Browne, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Mary Shelley, Thomas Carlyle, and Ralph Waldo Emerson, among others. It combines traditional historicism with contemporary theoretical practice, resulting in an interdisciplinary jargon-free critical narrative. Of particular interest to specialists in Melvillean studies, American Romanticism, and 19th-century American literature, it also will appeal to scholars of philosophy and literature, literature and culture, and literary criticism.
